title: Modeling a Periodic Context - Hour Hand of Clock

content.description:
The center of the clockface is represented by a small circle. 

Extending from the center are two hands that point to numbers on the clock. One of the hands is labeled Hour Hand.

The clockwise rotation direction for the Hour Hand is indicated.

Numbers on the clock are located near the clock’s perimeter. The numbers divide the clock into 12 sectors or sections. The number directly above the center is 12. Moving from the 12 to the right in a clockwise direction, the numbers appear as follows.

The figure shows a clock standing on a level floor with a close-up view of the clockface. The clockface has a <math alttext="10"><mn>10</mn></math>-centimeter-long hour hand that moves as time passes. The center of the clockface is <math alttext="200"><mn>200</mn></math> centimeters from the floor. At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> hours, the hour hand is pointing directly up to the <math alttext="12"><mn>12</mn></math>. The next time the hour hand points directly up to the <math alttext="12"><mn>12</mn></math> is at time <math alttext="t equals 12"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> hours. As the hour hand moves, the distance of the endpoint of the hour hand from the floor periodically decreases and increases.

The sinusoidal function <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> models the distance, in centimeters, of the endpoint of the hour hand from the floor as a function of time <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, in hours.

The <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 1"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and the <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 2"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
